abstract: Here we present qFlex, a flexible tensor network-based quantum circuit simulator. qFlex can compute both the exact amplitudes, essential for the verification of the quantum hardware, as well as low-fidelity amplitudes, to mimic sampling from Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices. In this work, we focus on random quantum circuits (RQCs) in the range of sizes expected for supremacy experiments. Fidelity f simulations are performed at a cost that is 1/f lower than perfect fidelity ones. We also present a technique to eliminate the overhead introduced by rejection sampling in most tensor network approaches. We benchmark the simulation of square lattices and Googleâ€™s Bristlecone QPU. Our analysis is supported by extensive simulations on NASA HPC clusters Pleiades and Electra. For our most computationally demanding simulation, the two clusters combined reached a peak of 20 Peta Floating Point Operations per Second (PFLOPS) (single precision), i.e., 64% of their maximum achievable performance, which represents the largest numerical computation in terms of sustained FLOPs and the number of nodes utilized ever run on NASA HPC clusters. Finally, we introduce a novel multithreaded, cache-efficient tensor index permutation algorithm of general application.
